title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is probability used for in real-life situations?

options.label: A
options.text: Only in weather forecasts

options.label: B
options.text: Only in making predictions in sports

options.label: C
options.text: In various areas such as weather forecasts, sports predictions, auto insurance rates, and casinos

options.label: D
options.text: In determining the odds of winning a game

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental counting principle in probability?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of possible outcomes for an event is equal to the sum of the possible outcomes for each individual event

options.label: B
options.text: The number of possible outcomes for an event is equal to the product of the possible outcomes for each individual event

options.label: C
options.text: The number of possible outcomes for an event is equal to the difference of the possible outcomes for each individual event

options.label: D
options.text: The number of possible outcomes for an event is equal to the quotient of the possible outcomes for each individual event

multiple-choice.question: If you were to randomly guess on a 10-question true/false quiz, what is the probability of getting a perfect score?
What is the expected average score if you and your friends were to randomly guess on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If there are 20 questions on a test with 5 possible answers for each question, what is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?

options.label: C
options.text: 1/95 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 1/100 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected number of questions you would get right by guessing on a 20-question test with 5 possible answers for each question?

options.label: A
options.text: 1/5 of 10 questions

options.label: B
options.text: 1/5 of 20 questions

options.label: C
options.text: 1/2 of 10 questions

options.label: D
options.text: 1/2 of 20 questions

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of multiplying 2 by itself 10 times (2^10)?
What is the result of multiplying 5 by itself 20 times (5^20)?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 million

options.label: B
options.text: 1 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 95 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 100 trillion

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not a good idea to randomly guess on a true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: Because you might get a perfect score

options.label: B
options.text: Because you might get a low score

options.label: C
options.text: Because the probability of getting a perfect score is very low

options.label: D
options.text: Because the probability of getting a perfect score is very high

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of studying for a quiz instead of guessing?

options.label: A
options.text: To get a perfect score

options.label: B
options.text: To get a high score

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the chances of getting a good score

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease the chances of getting a good score

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of authentic narrative in connecting people through media?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing factual information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a sense of urgency and action

options.label: C
options.text: Making the personal universal and transcending the individual

options.label: D
options.text: Presenting bulleted facts and updates

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of sourcing required in every well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, social media, and personal opinions

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Academics, consultants, and authors

options.label: D
options.text: Stakeholders, experts, and witnesses

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources provide the "why" and give consequence to an event or trend?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources

options.label: B
options.text: Overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Social media sources

multiple-choice.question: How can journalists mine for compelling stories and anecdotes?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking predictable questions

options.label: B
options.text: By asking surprising questions

options.label: C
options.text: By presenting bulleted facts and updates

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring unofficial sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of anecdotes in storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide additional facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: To breathe life into a grey story of exposition

options.label: C
options.text: To present bulleted information quickly

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the human connection

multiple-choice.question: When is it important to convey information quickly in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: When telling a personal story

options.label: B
options.text: When presenting an in-depth analysis

options.label: C
options.text: When a situation is urgent and action is required

options.label: D
options.text: When writing a feature article

multiple-choice.question: What type of storytelling has the luxury of a slow dance of information?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking news

options.label: B
options.text: In-depth analysis

options.label: C
options.text: Narrative personal stories

options.label: D
options.text: Social media updates

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of artful solicitation of story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present facts and data quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of urgency and action

options.label: C
options.text: To make the journalism memorable and deliver a narrative bond

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the human connection

multiple-choice.question: How can journalists regard the stories of every subject?

options.label: A
options.text: As irrelevant and unimportant

options.label: B
options.text: As sacred and worthy of attention

options.label: C
options.text: As mere facts and data

options.label: D
options.text: As social media fodder

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of narrative storytelling in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of urgency and action

options.label: C
options.text: To connect people to each other through a narrative bond

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the human connection

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: According to Emily Dickinson, what is the best way to be transported to new lands?

options.label: A
options.text: By watching a movie

options.label: B
options.text: By reading a book

options.label: C
options.text: By listening to music

options.label: D
options.text: By traveling by ship

multiple-choice.question: What do researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology claim to have found evidence for?

options.label: A
options.text: That stories have no impact on our point of view

options.label: B
options.text: That stories can only change our point of view temporarily

options.label: C
options.text: That stories have a unique ability to change a person's point of view

options.label: D
options.text: That stories can only shape our opinions on trivial matters

multiple-choice.question: What was significant about Samuel Richardson's novel "Pamela" when it was first published?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first novel to feature a male protagonist

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first novel to challenge traditional notions of class and marriage

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first novel to be written by a woman

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first novel to be set in a fantasy world

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what novels have helped shape the minds of thought leaders across history?

options.label: A
options.text: Only novels from the 18th century

options.label: B
options.text: Only novels from the 19th century

options.label: C
options.text: Novels such as "Pride and Prejudice", "Jane Eyre", and "Twilight"

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Intelligence

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: We should only read classic novels and ignore modern ones

options.label: B
options.text: We should only read modern novels and ignore classic ones

options.label: C
options.text: We should read classic novels, but also keep in mind that the terrain has changed

options.label: D
options.text: We should not read classic novels at all

options.label: A
options.text: What story will you try on next?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of using logarithms in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: To simplify complex equations

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with extremely small or large numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate the area of shapes

options.label: D
options.text: To find the volume of solids

multiple-choice.question: What is the logarithm of a number n, given a base number b and an exponent p?

options.label: A
options.text: The product of b and p

options.label: B
options.text: The quotient of n and b

options.label: C
options.text: The exponent p

options.label: D
options.text: The base number b

multiple-choice.question: How is the logarithm of a number typically written?

options.label: A
options.text: As the base number raised to the power of the exponent

options.label: B
options.text: As the exponent raised to the power of the base number

options.label: C
options.text: As "log, base b, of a number equals p, the power"

options.label: D
options.text: As "log, base p, of a number equals b, the base"

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
Why is log base 10 commonly used in sciences?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the only logarithm that can be calculated using a scientific calculator

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is used frequently in the sciences

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the simplest logarithm to calculate

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the most complex logarithm to calculate

What does pH measure in chemistry?

options.label: B
options.text: The temperature of a sample

options.label: C
options.text: The pressure of a sample

options.label: D
options.text: The volume of a sample

multiple-choice.question: How is pH calculated using logarithms?

options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals negative log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration

multiple-choice.question: Why do tears in our eyes have a pH of about 7.4?

options.text: Because it is the optimal pH for eye health

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the pH of pure water

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the pH that feels most comfortable on the eyes

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not explicitly stated in the transcript

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the example about the difference between point 0000000398 and point 00000000398 causing one to have red eyes after swimming?

options.label: A
options.text: To illustrate the importance of logarithms in chemistry

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the use of logarithms in calculating pH

options.label: C
options.text: To show how logarithms can be used to simplify complex calculations

options.label: D
options.text: To explain why some swimming pools cause eye irritation

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What was the first form of telling time?

options.label: A
options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Candle clock

multiple-choice.question: What is the object that casts a shadow in a sundial called?

options.label: A
options.text: Gnomon

options.label: B
options.text: Obelisk

options.label: C
options.text: Stick

options.label: D
options.text: Surface

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of sundials?

options.label: A
options.text: They require electricity to function

options.label: B
options.text: They require water to function

options.label: C
options.text: They require the sun to shine

options.label: D
options.text: They require a battery to function

multiple-choice.question: What is an hourglass?

options.label: A
options.text: A device that measures time using the sun's shadow

options.label: B
options.text: A device that measures time using the vibration of a quartz crystal

options.label: C
options.text: A device in which fine sand pours through a tiny hole at a constant rate

options.label: D
options.text: A device that measures time using the swing of a pendulum

multiple-choice.question: When was the mechanical clock invented?

options.label: A
options.text: 14th century

options.label: B
options.text: 13th century

options.label: C
options.text: 15th century

options.label: D
options.text: 16th century

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: A continuous count of seconds based on atomic clocks

options.label: B
options.text: A continuous count of minutes based on sundials

options.label: C
options.text: A continuous count of hours based on hourglasses

options.label: D
options.text: A continuous count of days based on calendars

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people all over the world

options.label: B
options.text: So we can ignore people in other time zones

options.label: C
options.text: So we can have multiple clocks showing different times

options.label: D
options.text: So we can disregard train schedules

multiple-choice.question: What is a time zone?

options.label: A
options.text: A region on earth with multiple standard times

options.label: B
options.text: A region on earth with a uniform standard time

options.label: C
options.text: A region on earth with no standard time

options.label: D
options.text: A region on earth with a variable standard time

multiple-choice.question: How many time zones are there on land?
Why was the use of time zones introduced?

options.label: A
options.text: To make communication more complicated

options.label: B
options.text: To make train schedules more confusing

options.label: C
options.text: To iron out differences in time between regions

options.label: D
options.text: To disregard calendars
